technical-data.invention-title: GLEICHSTROMVERSORGUNG MIT ECHTZEITSCHÄTZUNG DER DYNAMISCHEN IMPEDANZ
DC POWER SUPPLY UTILIZING REAL TIME ESTIMATION OF DYNAMIC IMPEDANCE
ALIMENTATION EN COURANT CONTINU UTILISANT UNE ESTIMATION EN TEMPS REEL DE L'IMPEDANCE DYNAMIQUE

description.heading: BACKGROUND OF THE INVENTION
Field of the Invention
description.p: This invention relates generally to any controller for a power supply that utilizes a compensator to shape the response of the control loop to external disturbances, and more particularly to a control means for calculating the dynamic impedance of a DC magnetron based process.
description.heading: Brief Description of the Prior Art
description.p: In plasma processing for the manufacture of thin films for integrated circuits, flat panel displays, glass coatings, etc a fast controller is required to effectively control the power delivered to a wide range of plasma processes. Controllers are designed accounting for the control to output transfer function of the power supply. The transfer function of the power supply depends on the dynamic impedance of the load. The primary function of a controller for a power supply is to achieve and maintain any commanded control signal. The controller is designed accounting for the control to output, and line to output transfer functions of the power supply. The dependence of the controller on load impedance may be in the form of DC gain, or the location of a pole or a zero in the transfer function of the power supply. Any change in the output impedance can significantly influence the performance of the control loop and sometimes even catastrophically by making a previously stable system unstable. As shown in Figure 1 the dynamic impedance is positive for curves A and B and negative for curve C. The voltage and resistance are a function of the operating point and can change with time. Figure 2 illustrates how depending on the process and plasma characteristics the plasma load can be modeled as a voltage source in series with a resistance. In the cases where variations in the transfer function due to a change in the dynamic impedance may be limited to the DC gain and could be easily compensated with analog circuitry or digital gain blocks, it is performed by a priori analysis of the transfer functions and implementing lookup tables for different load conditions.

Some controllers utilize DC current and the DC voltage to calculate the DC impedance of the plasma. However, this method has a disadvantage, since it assumes that the plasma represents a load that is only an impedance in nature. In the case of model plasma as shown in Figure 2 then an approach is to use an empirical value of the plasma voltage and subtract this from the DC voltage and then use this to calculate the actual dynamic impedance of the plasma. This approach has a disadvantage because there are wide ranges of internal voltages that even the same plasma can exhibit.

For instance, U. S. Patent No. 5,543,689 issued to Ryusuke Ohta et al discloses a high frequency power source wherein the controller has a memory for storing initial plasma characteristic data and plasma gain, a comparable operation section for calculating control target data from initial plasma characteristic data and detected power data and computing the control gain data from the difference between the control target data and the power control signal data. The control target data is derived by subtracting the initial plasma data from the detected plasma data. However, the process described relies upon an alarm for manual adjustment of the control signal. Such a system has a slow response time and may cause the process to shut down before correction can be made.
US 4,500,408 concerns a controller for a magnetron power supply to control the dynamic impedance of the magnetron plasma by measuring and adjusting plasma pressure.

These types of control schemes are undesirable because 1) estimation of the plasma resistance is extremely difficult; 2) implementation of the compensation is limited to the DC gain; 3) they are not continuous and dependence may not be monotonic with respect to the load impedance; and 4) the variation in the poles and zeros of the transfer function with the load impedance may still degrade the performance of the system and in some instances may also cause the system to go unstable. Also, faster loop speeds require ability to compensate for load and create transfer functions to create a fairly wide-band system.

It would be desirable if there were provided a controller for a DC power supply that utilized a fast control loop which works for a wide range of plasma processes. It would also be desirable if there were provided method of control which enables adaptive and non-linear control by estimating dynamic impedance of the load.
description.heading: SUMMARY OF THE INVENTION
description.p: There is provided by this invention a controller for a power supply such as a power supply for a DC magnetron process system that utilizes an analog to digital converter (ADC) in combination with a digital microprocessor to estimate the dynamic impedance of the plasma. An automatic control loop maintains the control signal for the power supply by sampling the output voltage and current of the power supply to correct for differences between the output and a predetermined control signal.

description.heading: BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF THE PREFERRED EMBODIMENTS
description.p: Referring to Figure 3 there is shown a plasma processing system 10 such as a DC magnetron processing system that incorporates the principles of this invention. A plasma chamber 12 has contained therein electrodes 14 and 16. A power supply 18 supplies a voltage to the electrodes 14 and 16 in order to ignite plasma 20 in a reactive gas (not shown). Particles from the plasma are disposed to deposit a thin film on a substrate (not shown) in the chamber. To compensate for changes in the output of the power supply 18 a controller 22 automatically adjusts the control signal 24 to the power supply based upon the change of the dynamic impedance of the plasma 20. The controller is generally comprised of an analog to digital converter 26 and microprocessor 28. The A/D converter samples the output voltage and current of the power supply and the values are inputted to the microprocessor which makes a real time estimation of the dynamic impedance of the plasma and sends a control signal 24 to the power supply to make output adjustments as necessary.
Figure 4 illustrates the typical transient to control signal post-plasma-ignition for the following algorithm: Rplasma=Δ⁢Vn-1Δ⁢In-1

Where ΔVn-1 represents the moving increment in plasma voltage over a fixed number of samples based upon the sampling frequency. ΔIn-1 represents the same value for the plasma current. This occurs when the absolute value of the increments in voltage and current are lower than the threshold. A predetermined threshold is chosen to estimate when the plasma reaches steady state. This threshold is chosen considering the sampling frequency and the power system dynamics. This enables the calculation of the dynamic impedance when the plasma is just about to reach the set point. It is to be noted that this algorithm enables the controller to estimate if the dynamic impedance being seen by the power supply is negative in nature, and compensate appropriately for negative impedance.

Figure 5 illustrates the flow chart used for estimating the dynamic impedance of the plasma. In the first step, depending on the sampling frequency, the A/D converter samples both the output voltage and current of the power supply. This method calculates the dynamic impedance prior to the plasma reaching the set point and not while the plasma is at set point. In order to measure the impedance at set point another digital measurement system utilizes the A/D converter sampling at a frequency higher than the power supply switching frequency ripple seen on the plasma current and voltage, which is usually the switching frequency or a multiple of it. This data can be used to estimate the dynamic impedance of the plasma. It is specifically possible to determine whether the dynamic impedance is positive or negative with this algorithm.

Figure 6 illustrates the estimation of the dynamic impedance from the switching ripple. In order to accomplish this task the sampling frequency is usually on the order of four or five times the ripple on the voltage and current. Then the maximum and minimum values of the voltage/current within an integral number of switching periods are estimated and the difference between them gives ΔVn and ΔIn. It is then possible to look for the maximum change in either the voltage or current and then use the change in the other parameter (current or voltage respectively) during the same time interval to calculate the dynamic impedance of the plasma. Rplasma=Δ⁢VnΔ⁢In

Figure 7 illustrates the flow chart for calculating the dynamic impedance from the switching ripple. The A/D converter acquires a new set of n samples for voltage and current. The microprocessor calculates the maximum and minimum of the given samples and the difference between them and assigns to delta V and delta I. The dynamic impedance is then calculated from these values. This algorithm specifically determines whether the dynamic impedance is negative or positive.

It must be noted here that the impedances calculated with the two methods are at two different frequencies. The one measured with the transient set up is at a frequency much closer to the control loop bandwidth. The one calculated using the switching frequency ripple is at a much higher frequency than the control loop bandwidth.. However, the impedance estimated using the switching ripple gives insight into the high-frequency performance of the plasma, and is useful for determining the fast dynamics of the plasma.

Although there is illustrated and described specific structure and details of operation, it is clearly understood that the same were merely for purposes of illustration and that changes and modifications may be readily made therein by those skilled in the art without departing from the scope of this invention.

claim.claim-text: Vorrichtung zur Steuerung eines Gleichstrom-Magnetronplasmaverarbeitungssystems (10), die Folgendes umfasst: a) eine Kammer (12), in der mindestens zwei Elektroden (14, 16) enthalten sind, für die Plasmaverarbeitung zur Abscheidung eines Dünnfilms auf einem Substrat; b) eine Stromversorgung (18), die so angeordnet ist, dass sie eine Spannung an die Elektroden (14,16) anlegt, um Plasma zu zünden und Energie bereitzustellen, und c) einen Controller (22), die an die Stromversorgung (18) angeschlossen ist und so angeordnet ist, dass er basierend auf einer Änderung der dynamischen Impedanz des Plasmas ein Steuersignal automatisch einstellt, das an die Stromversorgung (18) angelegt wird, um die Energie zu steuern, die an das Plasma angelegt wird.

Vorrichtung zur Steuerung eines Gleichstrom-Magnetronplasmaverarbeitungssystems (10) nach Anspruch 1, wobei der Controller (22) im Allgemeinen einen Analog-Digital-Wandler (26) zum Abtasten der Ausgangsspannung und des Ausgangsstroms der Stromversorgung (18) umfasst.

Vorrichtung zur Steuerung eines Gleichstrom-Magnetronplasmaverarbeitungssystems nach Anspruch 2, wobei der Controller (22) ferner einen Mikroprozessor (28) umfasst, der Eingaben von dem Analog-Digital-Wandler (26) empfängt, eine Echtzeitschätzung der dynamischen Impedanz des Plasmas vornimmt und ein Steuersignal zur Stromversorgung (18) sendet, um den Ausgangsenergie zu dem Plasma einzustellen.

Verfahren zur Steuerung eines Gleichstrom-Magnetronplasmaverarbeitungssystems für die Plasmaverarbeitung zur Abscheidung eines Dünnfilms auf einem Substrat, wobei das Verfahren folgende Schritte umfasst: Anlegen einer Ausgangsspannung und eines Ausgangsstroms an Elektroden mittels einer Stromversorgung, um ein Plasma zu zünden; Abtasten der Ausgangsspannung und des Ausgangsstroms in einem Analog-Digital-Wandler und basierend auf der abgetasteten Ausgangsspannung und dem abgetasteten Ausgangsstrom Vornehmen von Echtzeitschätzungen der dynamischen Impedanz des Plasmas zu verschiedenen Zeiten, um eine geschätzte Veränderung der dynamischen Impedanz des Plasmas zu erhalten; und automatisches Einstellen eines Steuersignals und Anlegen des Steuersignals an die Stromversorgung basierend auf der geschätzten Änderung der dynamischen Impedanz, um die Energie zu steuern, die an das Plasma angelegt wird.

Verfahren nach Anspruch 4, wobei: a) die Abtastung basierend auf einer Abtastfrequenz an einer Anzahl von Proben vorgenommen wird; b) die Echtzeitschätzung die Berechnung der dynamischen Impedanz des Plasmas basierend auf der abgetasteten Spannung und des abgetasteten Stroms von folgendem Algorithmus umfasst: Rplasma=Δ⁢Vn-1Δ⁢In-1
wodurch ΔVn-1 und ΔIn-1 aus Proben berechnet werden, kurz bevor das Plasma in den stationären Zustand übergeht, und c) das Verfahren die Schätzung, ob die erfasste dynamische Impedanz negativ ist, und entsprechendes Kompensieren umfasst.

Verfahren nach Anspruch 4, wobei: a) die Abtastung mit einer Abtastfrequenz durchgeführt wird, die mindestens vier bis mal höher als die Schaltfrequenzwelligkeit der Stromversorgung ist; b) die Echtzeitschätzung die Berechnung der dynamischen Impedanz des Plasmas basierend auf der abgetasteten Spannung und des abgetasteten Stroms von folgendem Algorithmus umfasst: Rplasma=Δ⁢VnΔ⁢In
wobei ΔVn und ΔIn die maximalen Differenzen zwischen Proben bei einem Schaltzyklus sind und c) das Verfahren die Schätzung, ob die erfasste dynamische Impedanz negativ ist, und daraufhin entsprechendes Kompensieren umfasst.

Apparatus for controlling a dc magnetron plasma processing system (10), comprising: a) a chamber (12) having at least two electrodes (14, 16) contained therein, for plasma processing to deposit a thin film on a substrate; b) a power supply (18) arranged to supply voltage to the electrodes (14,16) to ignite plasma and deliver power; and c) a controller (22) connected to the power supply (18) and arranged to automatically adjust a control signal provided to the power supply (18) based upon a change in dynamic impedance of the plasma, to control the power delivered to the plasma.

Apparatus for controlling a dc magnetron plasma processing system (10) as recited in claim 1 wherein the controller (22) is generally comprised of an analog to digital converter (26) for sampling the output voltage and output current of the power supply (18).

Apparatus for controlling a dc magnetron plasma processing system as recited in claim 2 wherein the controller (22) is further comprised of a microprocessor (28) which receives input from the analog to digital converter (26), makes a real time estimation of the dynamic impedance of the plasma, and sends a control signal to the power supply (18) to adjust the output power to the plasma.

A method of controlling a dc magnetron plasma processing system for plasma processing to deposit a thin film on a substrate, the method comprising the steps of: providing by a power supply an output voltage and current to electrodes to ignite a plasma; sampling the output voltage and current in an analog-to-digital converter and making real time estimations at different times of the dynamic impedance of the plasma based on the sampled output voltage and current, to obtain an estimated change of dynamic impedance of the plasma; and automatically adjusting a control signal and providing the control signal to the power supply based on the estimated change of dynamic impedance, to control the power delivered to the plasma.

A method as claimed in claim 4, wherein: a) the sampling is performed over a number of samples based upon a sampling frequency; b) the real time estimation comprises calculating the dynamic impedance of the plasma based upon the sampled voltage and current from the algorithm Rplasma=Δ⁢Vn-1Δ⁢In-1
whereby ΔVn-1 and ΔIn-1 are calculated from samples just before plasma gets to the steady-state condition; and c) the method comprises estimating if the dynamic impedance seen is negative in nature and compensating accordingly.

A method as claimed in claim 4, wherein: a) the sampling is performed at a sampling frequency at least four to five times higher than the power supply switching frequency ripple; b) the real time estimation comprises calculating the dynamic impedance of the plasma based upon the sampled voltage and current from the algorithm Rplasma=Δ⁢VnΔ⁢In
wherein ΔVn and ΔIn are the maximum differences among samples on one switching cycle; and c) the method comprises estimating if the dynamic impedance is negative and then compensating accordingly.

Un appareil de commande d'un système de traitement par plasma magnétron à courant continu (10), comprenant : a) une chambre (12) possédant au moins deux électrodes (14, 16) contenues dans celle-ci pour un traitement par plasma destiné à déposer un film mince sur un substrat, b) une alimentation électrique (18) agencée de façon à fournir une tension aux électrodes (14, 16) pour allumer un plasma et fournir une énergie électrique, et c) un dispositif de commande (22) raccordé à l'alimentation électrique (18) et agencé de façon à ajuster automatiquement un signal de commande fourni à l'alimentation électrique (18) en fonction d'un changement dans une impédance dynamique du plasma, de façon à commander l'énergie électrique fournie au plasma.

L'appareil de commande d'un système de traitement par plasma magnétron à courant continu (10) selon la Revendication 1 où le dispositif de commande (22) se compose généralement d'un convertisseur analogique à numérique (26) destiné à échantillonner la tension et le courant en sortie de l'alimentation électrique (18).

L'appareil de commande d'un système de traitement par plasma magnétron à courant continu selon la Revendication 2 où le dispositif de commande (22) se compose en outre d'un microprocesseur (28) qui reçoit une entrée provenant du convertisseur analogique à numérique (26), effectue une estimation en temps réel de l'impédance dynamique du plasma et envoie un signal de commande à l'alimentation électrique (18) de façon à ajuster l'énergie en sortie vers le plasma.

Un procédé de commande d'un système de traitement par plasma magnétron à courant continu pour un traitement par plasma destiné à déposer un film mince sur un substrat, le procédé comprenant les opérations suivantes : la fourniture par une alimentation électrique d'une tension et d'un courant en sortie à des électrodes de façon à allumer un plasma, l'échantillonnage de la tension et du courant en sortie dans un convertisseur analogique à numérique et l'exécution d'estimations en temps réel à différents instants de l'impédance dynamique du plasma en fonction de la tension et du courant en sortie échantillonnés de façon à obtenir un changement estimé d'impédance dynamique du plasma, et l'ajustement automatique d'un signal de commande et la fourniture du signal de commande à l'alimentation électrique en fonction du changement estimé d'impédance dynamique de façon à commander l'énergie électrique fournie au plasma.

Un procédé selon la Revendication 4, où : a) l'échantillonnage est exécuté sur un nombre d'échantillons en fonction d'une fréquence d'échantillonnage, b) l'estimation en temps réel comprend le calcul de l'impédance dynamique du plasma en fonction de la tension et du courant échantillonnés à partir de l'algorithme Rplasma=Δ⁢Vn-1Δ⁢In-1
grâce à quoi ΔVn-1 et ΔIn-1 sont calculés à partir d'échantillons juste avant que le plasma ne passe à la condition d'état stable, et c) le procédé comprend l'estimation si l'impédance dynamique observée est négative par nature et une compensation en conséquence.

Un procédé selon la Revendication 4, où : a) l'échantillonnage est exécuté à une fréquence d'échantillonnage au moins quatre à cinq fois supérieure à l'ondulation de la fréquence de commutation de l'alimentation électrique, b) l'estimation en temps réel comprend le calcul de l'impédance dynamique du plasma en fonction de la tension et du courant échantillonnés à partir de l'algorithme Rplasma=Δ⁢VnΔ⁢In
où ΔVn et ΔIn sont les différences maximales parmi les échantillons sur un cycle de commutation, et c) le procédé comprend l'estimation si l'impédance dynamique est négative et alors une compensation en conséquence.
